title: Mayoral preliminary: Wu maintains huge lead over Kraft as both advance to November election
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Mayor Michelle Wu leads with over 45% more votes than Josh Kraft, advancing to November's Boston mayoral election.
Josh Kraft, accompanied by family, vows strong effort despite trailing Wu significantly in preliminary election results.
Boston mayoral race sees nearly 18% voter turnout, with over 75,000 ballots cast, according to the Elections Department.

title: What to know about the viral surrogacy lawsuit
author: Audrey Cooney
bullets: Cindy Bi, a venture capitalist, sued surrogate Rebecca Smith, accusing her of intentionally causing miscarriage.
The surrogacy industry is expected to grow significantly, but lacks comprehensive regulation, Wired reports.
Smith moved and changed jobs due to harassment and lawsuits initiated by Bi following the miscarriage.

title: A healthy Hampus Lindholm could change Bruins’ fortunes in several areas
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Hampus Lindholm returns healthy for Boston Bruins' training camp after missing final 65 games last season.
Lindholm aims to improve Bruins' power play, which ranked 29th in NHL with a 15.2% success rate last season.
Lindholm offers stability to Bruins' defense, hopes to boost team performance after their 33-39-10 record in 2024.

title: Drake Maye receives a ringing endorsement from Bills QB Josh Allen
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Josh Allen praises Patriots QB Drake Maye for his skills and authenticity on the 'Like a Farmer' podcast.
Drake Maye, compared to Josh Allen, was described as a 'mini Josh Allen' by Bill Simmons of The Ringer.
Maye posted 287 yards, one touchdown, and one interception in Patriots' season-opener loss to the Raiders.

title: MBTA debuts train design to honor historic New England railroad, with more on the way
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: The MBTA debuts a Boston and Maine Railroad train design, featuring maroon and yellow colors, on the Commuter Rail.
Two additional trains honoring New Haven and New York Central railroads are expected to enter service by year-end.
The revamped trains, part of 37 overhauled locomotives, include upgrades like remote monitoring and modern brake systems.

title: Patriots could be facing off against their former 1st-round pick in Miami
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots' former first-round pick Cole Strange joins Miami Dolphins from Cleveland Brownsâ€™ practice squad.
Strange, drafted by Patriots in 2022, played 29 games but faced injuries, including a torn patellar tendon.
Dolphins need Strange as a contingency plan after starting guard James Daniels' pectoral injury in Week 1.

title: Tufts to go tuition-free for families making less than $150K
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Tufts University to waive tuition for undergraduates whose families earn less than $150,000 starting next fall.
Students from families earning under $60,000 will receive financial aid packages with no student loans at Tufts.
Tufts allocates over $143 million for financial aid in 2026 to support students from lower-income families.

title: Aunt now caring for young daughter of parents killed in Watertown murder-suicide
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: David Minasvand killed Karine Asatryan and Nadia Abrahamian before committing suicide in Watertown, leaving a 1-year-old daughter.
Madeline, the daughter of Asatryan and Minasvand, will be cared for by her aunt, Meline Asatryan, according to a fundraiser.
Over $37,000 has been raised to support Madeline's needs, including childcare, medical care, and future education.

title: What Don Sweeney said about the Bruins’ playoff odds, timeline for new captain
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Don Sweeney expects the Bruins to be competitive in the 2025-26 season despite uncertainty about playoff prospects.
Bruins plan to rely on young talent and signings like Tanner Jeannot to fill the roster, aiming for a defensive rebound.
The Bruins will start the season without a set captain as the leadership develops organically with David Pastrnak and Charlie McAvoy as frontrunners.

title: These 5 New England restaurants make best 50 list from NYT
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Five New England restaurants made The New York Times' list of 50 best restaurants in the U.S.
Boston restaurants McGonagle's and La Padrona are recognized for their Irish and Italian cuisines.
Restaurants in Maine and Connecticut, but not Rhode Island, Vermont, or New Hampshire, featured on the list.
